Award.AwardTitle: Field and Laboratory Program to Evaluate Atlantic Intermediate Circulation During the Past 25,000 Years
Award.AbstractNarration:
In this project, the PIs will study how changes in deep ocean circulation influenced the distribution of heat, nutrients, and carbon within the ocean, and their link to earth's climate and levels of CO2 in the atmosphere. The research will test the hypothesis that the northward flow of Antarctic Intermediate Water (AAIW) in the Atlantic Ocean is linked to its role as a supplier of North Atlantic Deep Water (NADW), which derives from sinking of surface waters at high northern latitudes and then flows southward in the Atlantic. The PIs predict that when NADW fills more of the deep Atlantic, AAIW penetrates farther northward to supply NADW. In contrast, during abrupt cold events when the formation of NADW was disrupted, the northward penetration of AAIW would have decreased. To address this hypothesis, the PIs will collect new sediment cores from the western tropical Atlantic (~8 N) using the new RV Knorr long coring system. Stable isotope and Mg/Ca data from fossil foraminifera will be used to generate time series of water mass tracers from depths spanning all subsurface water masses, including AAIW and NADW. Better knowledge of the history of the distribution of these water masses will provide a clearer understanding of how deep ocean circulation changes influence climate and atmospheric CO2.
The broader impact of this research includes the participation of four graduate and one undergraduate students on the cruise. One graduate student will use the new material for thesis research while an undergraduate will develop a website focusing on the cruise and its scientific significance. Data obtained from this project will be archived with the NGDC website and will be included in historical reconstructions used to improve simulations of past ocean circulation and to test the suitability of general circulation models to predict future climate change. The sediment will be available to other investigators.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This grant supported a three-week cruise to collect depth transects of sediment cores and water samples at the Demerara Rise, a bathymetric high in the western tropical Atlantic and to produce initial stratigraphies to confirm the quality of the cores for subsequent work. Our primary target was sediment bathed by modern Antarctic Intermediate Water (AAIW), to acquire material to reconstruct the history of AAIW flow into the North Atlantic.  We collected 12 long (~26-32m) piston cores from stations ranging in water depth from ~550 to 3100 m. Five of these cores are from the depth range of modern AAIW, as indicated by low salinities at the core depths.  We also collected 31 gravity cores and 22 multicores from stations between ~380 and 3300 m water depths.  We collected seawater samples at several CTD stations for geochemical analysis, and a bottom water sample at every multicore site. We also collected large volume water samples from two depths at one CTD station for an inter-calibration effort spearheaded by the WHOI NOSAMS facility.  Our post-cruise efforts have focused on seawater and core-top geochemical analysis, detailed benthic isotope stratigraphy and dating of one long core, and high-resolution X-ray fluorescence (XRF) stratigraphies of two long cores and 21 gravity cores. 

Five graduate students from five institutions and one undergraduate student (now a graduate student at Columbia U.) participated on our cruise.  With PI guidance, students developed a website providing background for our cruise. They kept a blog, annotated with 100’s of photos. Three other undergraduates and 5 high school students helped sample the cores and wash samples, and pick foraminifera for isotope and elemental analysis.  The 3 undergraduates all began as high school part-time helpers and are now majoring in ocean and geological sciences, or engineering. Oppo mentored a Winter 2010 high school student science fair project working on Demerara Rise sediment who won first prizes at the school, regional, and state (MIT) science fairs, and presented her project at a special high school competition at the 2011 AAAS Annual Meeting.  Only 8 high school students from Massachusetts were awarded the honor of participating at the AAAS meeting.  We also provided material to different students for Winter 2011 and 2012 High School science fair projects, for a college winter intern (from Williams College), and mentored a post-doctoral scientist. We’ve also provided samples for the thesis work of a graduate student at the University of Colorado, Boulder.

Our core-top results show that we can use several different, complementary approaches to reconstruct past Atlantic circulation. We presented our initial down-core and core-top results at the 2010 and 2011 Fall AGU meetings (Curry & Broda, 2010; Oppo et al., 2011, Huang et al., 2011), and have written a peer-reviewed paper for the Nature Education Knowledge Project, for undergraduate students, that includes a new carbon isotope western Atlantic transect for Heinrich event 1 (Oppo & Curry, 2012).
